Create a daily itinerary based on the given information.

Our family is looking for a 9-day Morocco trip that has light to moderate activity levels. We are interested in exploring Marrakesh, Fes, Merzouga, and Fez. We’d like to camp and spend two nights in the Sahara Desert, then ride camels into the dunes. We are also interested in visiting nearby historical and cultural attractions, such as tombs and castles. We are planning on leaving from Canada and would like a travel package that includes airfare, transportation, accommodations, and some meals. Are there any itineraries you could suggest that would be suitable for a family with moderate activity levels? Would be much appreciated.

Answer: What you've asked might be challenging to plan due to the time crunch you gave us. With that said, the following itinerary should get you covered. It is based on three day trips covering Marrakesh, Fes and Merzouga. In day 9, you will go back to Marrakesh to continue exploring the city. All day trips are done privately with your guide and driver, so you can ask them to stop when you choose and make your own itinerary. Also, the trip includes daily breakfast and dinner so that you do not have to cook or search out places for food.

Day 1: After receiving you at Marrakesh Airport, go to the city center and visit the Djemaa el-Fna Square. Have lunch in the square or one of the cafes nearby and take a stroll in the souks. In the evening, go to Djemaa el-Fna Square for dinner. This is a traditional Moroccan experience where you will have a panoramic view of the different restaurants in the square and taste different delicacies of the cuisine. Do not miss the lamps and the smells of the traditional pharmacy. Finally, go back to your accommodation in Marrakesh.

Day 2: In the morning, visit Bahia Palace and the Saadian Tombs. Then, go to the souks for lunch and start with spice stalls before you move on to leather and textiles. If time permits, visit Bahia Palace, which was once a private palace of the Alaoui dynasty and now serves as a museum. In the evening, stroll or visit the Yves Saint Laurent Museum or have dinner at a restaurant in the city center and enjoy the nightlife of Marrakesh.

Day 3: In the morning, drive to Fez (01hour), where you will spend two nights for exploration. On your first day, visit Medersa Bou Inania, one the most famous religious schools of the city. Then, visit the leather tanneries which give unique color to the city. Afterward, visit the Fez Souks, an iconic place for spices, ceramics, and carpets. In the evening, enjoy a dinner in a traditional restaurant with live music.

Day 4: In the morning, after breakfast, go to Fez el-Bali, the old city that dates back to the 11th century. There you will visit the Karaouine Mosque, the oldest university in the world. Then, visit the famous Moulay Idriss II Mausoleum or do some shopping in the Souks. Lunch at a local restaurant after exploring the city. Then, drive to Merzouga, the center of the Sahara Desert.

Day 5: After receiving you at Merzouga Hotel in Morocco, go to the desert. Take a camel ride and enjoy the sunset in the great dunes of the Sahara desert. The ride takes around 10 to 30 minutes to arrive to the camp in the desert. Enjoy dinner and sleep overnight in a tent.

Day 6: After having breakfast in the camp, take a camel ride to explore the desert. The ride typically takes around 1 to 2 hours to arrive back to the camp. After lunch, drive to Rissani, one of the oldest cities in Morocco, then continue to Erfoud. Spend some time exploring the beautiful village of Skoura and the famous Bled M’Gouna, a stunning palm grove, surrounded by beautiful Berber houses. In the evening, enjoy dinner and overnight at the hotel in Erfoud.

Day 7: After breakfast in the hotel, we will drive to Fes. Have Lunch at a local restaurant. In the evening, spend some time exploring the city of

instruction: Give students tips on how to keep their nerves under control during class presentations.
output_1:
1. Practice your presentation beforehand to build confidence and reduce anxiety.
2. Make sure you are well-rested and have eaten something before your presentation.
3. Take deep breaths to help calm your mind and body.
4. Visualize yourself delivering the presentation with confidence.
5. Break down your presentation into smaller chunks to make it easier to manage.
6. Remind yourself that your audience wants you to succeed.
7. Focus on the message you are delivering, not on yourself.
8. Remember to speak slowly and clearly to keep your nerves in check.
9. If you make a mistake, don't worry about it - just move on.
10. Reward yourself after a successful presentation.
output_2:
Give students tips on how to keep their nerves under control during class presentations. Suggest that they read a book on public speaking, practice in front of a mirror, and even try performing on a stage if they're brave enough.
34. Pull an Epiphany.
When in doubt, follow the example set by Socrates, who famously proclaimed, "I know that I know nothing."
When faced with a question or problem, the epiphany approach involves admitting what you don't know, and then looking for an answer from other experts or from your own research. Encourage students to embrace that mindset throughout the school year.
35. Bring Them Together.
If your class is divided on a sensitive issue, bring everyone together to discuss it. Not only will this promote better communication among your students, but it will encourage them to see things from other perspectives.
If you are unsure about whether your plan is a good idea – don't be afraid to try it! You can always adjust and adjust again over time, trying different strategies, and adapting to your students' needs.
37. Allow time off.
Teaching is a demanding job and teachers tend to be driven by a passion for education. Sometimes burnout and exhaustion occur even before the end of the school year, leading to resignation and a frustration that teachers are not supported. Remember to offer the teachers breaks for healthy self-caring. It makes it less likely that teachers will leave the profession.
We hope these teachers retention strategies will be helpful to teachers in developing countries. We would like to hear from you about what works in your settings and what doesn’t work. Please let us know if you have any suggestions to offer. Let’s work together to provide better education services in low-income countries!

instruction:
Think of an idea to help you win a challenge given to you. Write the steps you need to take to develop the idea as well.

What can you make by recycling and repurposing some old, previously used materials? We want to see it!
Projects must incorporate some kind of used materials - take that old used thing, and turn it into something new and different!
E-waste is a huge problem. What can you make using old electronics and other salvageable electronic materials? 
We have a special judges prize for our favorite Instructable that incorporates or is related to reusing e-waste.
Be smart and be safe; note that potentially deadly projects (like Lichtenberg/fractal wood burning machines) will not be allowed to be published or submitted to this contest.
output_1:
Step 1: Gather used materials: Collect used materials such as old electronics, scrap metal, wood, plastic, and fabric.

Step 2: Brainstorm ideas: Brainstorm ideas for how you can repurpose and recycle these materials, keeping in mind the challenge and the special judges prize related to reusing e-waste.

Step 3: Research: Research similar projects and tutorials to get an idea of what is possible and what has been done before.

Step 4: Create a plan: Create a plan on how you will turn your idea into reality, including what tools and materials you will need.

Step 5: Execute: Execute your plan, making sure to be safe and follow safety protocols.

Step 6: Document: Document your progress and write a tutorial for other people to follow.

Step 7: Publish: Publish your Instructable and submit it to the contest.
output_2:
Think of an idea to help you win a challenge given to you. Write the steps you need to take to develop the idea as well.

What can you make by recycling and repurposing some old, previously used materials? We want to see it!
Projects must incorporate some kind of used materials - take that old used thing, and turn it into something new and different!
E-waste is a huge problem. What can you make using old electronics and other salvageable electronic materials? 
We have a special judges prize for our favorite Instructable that incorporates or is related to reusing e-waste.
Be smart and be safe; note that potentially deadly projects (like Lichtenberg/fractal wood burning machines) will not be allowed to be published or submitted to this contest.

Electronic devices - old TVs, radios, phones, computers, stereo equipment and any other electronic gadgets. These electronics must be readily available and accessible to everyone who participates. A typical home should have a supply of these materials. Materials that are not readily available to everyone should not be used as part of the project.

Household Items - old clothes, hats, shoes, household items (lamps, dishes, bowls, etc) , junk yard scraps, wood, cardboard, old furniture, toys, etc.

Materials that are toxic (hazardous), flammable or dangerous must not be included in your project (such as CRTs, PCBs).

The judging will be tough, so make sure your Instructable is well thought-out and has great photos. Our judges will be looking at how well your project is executed, your creativity, and originality. They will also be looking for good technique, thoughtfulness, and workmanship. Best of all, this contest is about learning and sharing; our judges will take these factors into account when judging the entries. The winner should be an instructable that teaches something, is well organized and executed, and inspires.

There are two categories: Junior category: For participants who are under 18 years old.
Senior category: For participants who are 18 years old.

The contest has 1 category: E-waste and Salvage Contest.

The contest was originally submitted on May 8th, 2018 by Anonymous.

## Judging Criteria

1. Originality: Did the maker create and execute a project that stands out and is different from others?

2. Workmanship: Are the pieces well-thought out, well-organized and well-executed?

3. Teaching value: Is it clear how to execute the project, and is there added knowledge to teach and encourage others

4. Photos: Are the photos clear, well lit and high-quality?

5. Creativity: Is the project inspired by something special or distinctive? Does it bring something to the table that we haven't seen before or do something new with old materials? (For this contest, it is specifically about reuse and repurposing of old materials)

6. Safety: Is it safe to make and use the device or project, taking into account the materials used, the techniques and the final result?

7. Dual Functionality: Is the final device or product useful beyond the project itself? Can it be used in other areas and provide value in other creative or practical ways?

8. Technical Excellence: Does the maker show a clear understanding of the project or device and demonstrate advanced or exceptional technical knowledge in the fields of electronics, mechanics, construction or any other area pertinent to the project execution?

9. Awareness: Does the maker show how their project is relevant to the ongoing discussion of e-waste, sustainability and other contemporary topics?

10. Worthiness: Does the project inspire and encourage others to be more environmentally aware, eco-friendly, and sustainable in their practice?

In short, the judges will be looking at how well the participant executed their idea, showcased their creativity and originality, provided educational value as well as provided a sustainable solution to the problem of e-waste and recycling.

## Reward Details

instruction:
Provide a detailed explanation of the steps that are required in order to construct the given project.

Steam Engine Using an Empty Beer Can
output_1:
Step 1: Gather the Supplies: To build a steam engine using an empty beer can, you will need the following supplies: an empty beer can, a small rubber stopper, a length of copper tubing, a needle valve, a length of plastic tubing, a small piece of wood, a rubber band, a small metal clip or clamp, a small jar of Vaseline, and some tools such as scissors, a drill, a small wrench, and a soldering iron.

Step 2: Prepare the Beer Can: Cut the top off of the empty beer can with scissors. Then drill a hole in the bottom of the can and cut a small hole in the side of the can.

Step 3: Connect the Tubing: Place the stopper in the top of the beer can and insert the length of copper tubing through the hole in the bottom. Secure the copper tubing with the metal clip or clamp. Connect the plastic tubing to the copper tubing and secure it with the rubber band.

Step 4: Assemble the Parts: Insert the needle valve into the copper tubing and tighten it with the small wrench. Place a small dab of Vaseline on the needle valve to ensure a good seal.

Step 5: Attach the Wood: Attach the piece of wood to the side of the beer can with the rubber band. This will be used to hold the steam engine in place while it is running.

Step 6: Test the Engine: Place the engine in a bowl of hot water and turn the needle valve to allow the steam to pass through the engine. If the engine runs smoothly, it is ready to use.
output_2:
Provide a detailed explanation of the steps that are required in order to construct the given project.

Steam Engine Using an Empty Beer Can to Create Boiling Steam

We plan to construct a steam engine that relies on the principle of latent heat to produce heat from cold water. The steam engine will be simple to build and use; it just requires an empty beer can, a piece of wire, and an insulated container to house the water and steam. The can itself is capable of absorbing and holding a significant amount of heat, and its use for transportation will show the latent heat law in use. The wire will be used to attach a paddle wheel to the can and thus create a basic mechanism for driving the can around a circular path. The insulated container will be designed to prevent the water from losing heat as much as possible, ensuring that the steam is produced at a steady rate.

This project was inspired by the works of the famous inventor James Watt. It would be exciting to have at hom and test it. We are aiming to show that by using thermodynamics, we can use heat trapped inside a solid object to create a temperature gradient, thus creating a gradient in pressure, which can rotate a machine.

The first step in the project would be to gather our materials needed for the construction. In order to construct a steam engine, we would need an empty beer can, a wire with a length of either one or three or four meters, an insulated container, and some water. After we gathered our tools, we could proceed to the construction process.

The first step in the construction process would be to drill a small hole somewhere in the top of the beer can in the center of the can. Once the hole is drilled through, we would need to secure the wire to the center of the can with the help of the small hole as an aid. Once the hole is drilled and the wire is fixed to the center of the can, the next step would be to use a hot air gun or a blowtorch to melt the plastic or aluminum around the can and wire. This step is important to help ensure the wire will not slip out of place while still providing a better grip for the paddle wheel.

The next step would be to attach a paddle wheel to the wire. The paddle wheel can be crafted from any solid thin material that can handle both the stress and force of the wheel itself and should be able to handle the heat without melting or breaking apart. Once the paddle wheel is attached to the can and its center is lined up with the center of the can, one wire would need to be attached to the center of the paddle wheel, as shown below.

An insulated container will be used for keeping the temperature of the can in a steady state. The container can be any size but should be large enough to fit an empty beer can. It should also be able to withstand the temperature of the hot beer can without getting melted or burned. The insulated container should have an opening at the top large enough to fit an empty beer can, and it should close shut with a latch on its cover.

Once we have gathered all of our necessary materials and constructed the wire and paddle wheel, we would need to pour water into the insulated container until it begins to fill up the container.

The water in the insulated container would be heated by the hot water we poured in the beer can. The warm water will rise up to the surface, and since the beer can is now full of water and is covered by the insulated container, the beer can will be heated up. The hotter water inside the beer can will cause the water on the outside of the can to boil. The water inside the beer can will become steam as the temperature increases. The steam will escape out of the sides and top of the beer can since the beer can is open. The paddle wheel of the steel wire will spin around as steam escapes and the beer can is moved around the container. The steam is created by the latent heat contained within the water; the liquid loses its heat while changing into steam. The steam, hotter than the water, is pushing the water out of the can and into the container. The escape of the hot steam will drive the wheel, causing the can to spin around inside the insulated container.

The project is an exciting way to educate students about the principle of latent heat, and it can also be a fun and interactive way of learning science. Many people are unaware of heat and the effect it can have on the world around them, and this project gives individuals a way to observe scientific phenomena in real life. It teaches people about

instruction: Develop a mental exercise that can help people manage their anxiety and explain how it works.
output_1:
The Mental Exercise:

1. Start by taking a few deep breaths and focusing on your breath. Let your thoughts come and go without judgment or attachment.

2. Imagine a place, scene, or situation that makes you feel relaxed and at peace. Visualize yourself in this place and the feelings of calm and relaxation that come with it.

3. Focus on those feelings and let them fill your body.

4. Now let those feelings of relaxation move up to your mind. Notice the way your thoughts start to slow down and become more focused.

5. Once you have achieved a sense of relaxation, start to focus on positive affirmations. Repeat these affirmations to yourself or out loud if you feel comfortable doing so. Examples of positive affirmations include: 

“I am in control of my emotions.” 
“I am strong and capable.” 
“I am brave and have the power to face my fears.” 

6. Continue to repeat these affirmations until you feel a sense of calm and peace.

7. Finally, take a few more deep breaths and focus on your breath. Open your eyes and come back to the present moment feeling relaxed and at ease.

This mental exercise helps people manage their anxiety by providing a sense of relaxation and focusing on positive affirmations. It allows people to take a step back from the anxious thoughts and feelings and focus on positive and calming thoughts. By visualizing a peaceful place and repeating positive affirmations, people can feel more in control of their emotions and better able to cope with their anxiety.
output_2:
Develop a mental exercise that can help people manage their anxiety and explain how it works. This exercise can be used regularly. Give an example of a physical exercise that can help people manage their anxiety and explain how it works. This exercise can be used regularly. Explain what is meant by ‘reality testing’, as one strategy to manage anxiety. Reality testing involves attempting to view things as they really are rather than distorting them by attaching exaggerated negative connotations. Examples of reality testing techniques include: 1. Examining facts related to stressful circumstances and weighing them against what is most probable; 2. Asking others whose opinion you trust for guidance and perspective; 3. Taking time to re-assess what you can and can’t control, and to prioritize; 4. Recognizing the link between anxiety and lack of action when it comes to avoidance; 5. Using thought-stopping techniques to bring about greater perspective and calm, including counting to ten or repeating affirmations. Note: it’s important to seek professional help for issues or challenges that may be beyond one’s coping abilities.
5. 5 Examine your knowledge and understanding of anxiety and explain how it is understood and assessed by mental health professionals. Anxiety disorders are classed as mental health problems that can affect individuals, families or communities. These disorders can cause significant distress, including emotional and physical symptoms. Some of these disorders are: 1. General anxiety disorder (GAD): characterised by persistent and excessive worry without an obvious cause; 2. Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD): characterised by unwanted and repeated thoughts, behaviours or sensations, affecting daily life; 3. Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD): characterised by symptoms that persist for more than a month following a critical event, such as a natural disaster, violent crime or accident; 4. Phobias: characterised by an irrational and persistent fear of objects or situations that pose no real danger; 5. Social anxiety disorder: characterised by intense anxiety in social situations, such as meeting new people or public speaking; 6. Panic disorder: characterised by unexpected panic attacks, which can include hyperventilation, sensations of impending doom, and a sense of losing control; 7. Agoraphobia: characterised by a fear of or avoidance of places that might trigger a panic attack; 8. Specific phobias: characterised by abnormal and unrealistic fears of specific things, places or people; 9. Other conditions involving anxiety such as trichotillomania, excoriation, pica and body dysmorphia; Mental health professionals or healthcare providers may assess or diagnose an anxiety disorder through the use of standardised questionnaires or checklists. These may include: 1. Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (5th edition) – used for mental disorder diagnosis; 2. Hamilton Anxiety Scale – a tool used to quantitatively assess anxiety levels; 3. Symptom Checklist-90-Revision (SCL-90-R) – a screening instrument used to determine whether individuals meet criteria for various anxiety disorders; 4. Clinical Global Impression (CGI) scale – a tool used to help professionals rate overall treatment response over time; 5. Other tools may be used to assess the severity, frequency and impact of anxiety symptoms.
6. 6 Examine how you might support a friend or family member who may be experiencing anxiety. Remember that everyone’s experience of anxiety is unique to them, and that anxiety may look different in each individual. Be an attentive listener during any conversations about anxiety. Some suggestions of how you might support a friend or family member who may be experiencing anxiety include: 1. Be non-judgemental and supportive – avoid making comments that suggest blame or shame towards the individual struggling with anxiety. Avoid suggesting that a person has a ‘choice’ over their anxiety or should simply ‘get over it’; 2. Avoid giving advice – instead of offering ‘suggestions’ that might just be ignored, it may be more effective to listen and encourage the person to explore their feelings; 3. Encourage relaxation techniques – some activities such meditation, deep breathing exercises have been found to be helpful for managing anxiety; 4. Assist with problem-solving and help them identify resources, support systems and strategies

instruction: Design a template table for keeping track of all subscriptions.
output_1:
Subscription Name | Cost | Payment Method | Renewal Date | Cancellation Date
------------------|------|---------------|--------------|------------------
  |  |  |  |
output_2:
Design a template table for keeping track of all subscriptions. Each user, subscription type, and expiration time goes in separate columns
. Add a column that's labeled "Expired Date" if you're going to be deleting expired subscriptions.
. To stay organized, the left column should be named with the subscription date, and the top row should be labeled with the subscription type. A blank cell should be left for the date of the most recent subscription.
4. Create a Google Sheet Form to collect new subscriptions
. Use this form to help you collect data about subscribers and their subscriptions with a minimal amount of effort. The form can be modified to collect whatever data you need, but you'll want to have specifics about each user's unique subscription and expiration date.
. You can use a Google Sheet to collect input from the form and populate other cells in the table.
5. Create a Google Drive Folder for each mailing list
It's best to start keeping all of your mailing list communication materials in one place: Google Drive.
. You can use Google Drive for a centralized location to store important documents (like your list of subscribers), any email templates you use for sending messages, and related files.
6. Create your Mailchimp or Constant Contact account
. Most email marketing services require an account to access their service. Signing up for either service can be done with relative ease, and most importantly, they are cost-effective options that will allow you to scale your email marketing campaigns across audiences.
7. Make sure you have permission to send emails
Mailchimp requires that you obtain permission from subscribers to send them emails that are compliant with the CAN-SPAM Act. Be sure to check CAN-SPAM's rules and regulations here.
Additionally, it's best to have a preference center where subscribers can see and modify their information at any time -- so they can remove themselves from your list, update their account information, or view recent email communication you've had with them.
8. Use segmentation and campaign creation in your email marketing tool
. To ensure that you're sending personalized emails to each subscriber, make sure you use segmentation and campaign creation features available through your email marketing tool. For example, you can create a campaign that's aimed at subscribers who visit your site from a particular location or visit specific pages, and send it only to that designated audience. By doing some minimal A/B testing, you can also determine what works for your subscribers and what doesn't.
9. Get the correct approval for emails before sending
If your platform requires it, make sure your team gets approval for emails before sending. Approvals can be put in place to ensure that all emails make sense from brand perspective and are free from grammatical errors. With approvals, email messages can be sent, which increases visibility of the message, even when it's only sent out to a select audience.
10. Re-engage subscribers and update email list cleanliness
. Your email communication should be relevant to subscribers and provide value to them, so they're interested in receiving your emails. When a subscriber has been inactive for a while (let's say, not opening your email in the last six months), they're a high-risk subscriber. Email re-engagement can help keep your list clean. Re-engagement email campaigns can be designed to encourage subscribers to take particular actions-- like filling out a survey or clicking through a sign-up form -- which can help renew their engagement.
11. Adopt new email marketing metrics for your Mailchimp or Constant Contact account
. With Mailchimp or Constant Contact, you'll be able to track various email marketing metrics such as open rate, click rate, and even opt-out rates. These metrics will help you measure how well your email marketing campaign has succeeded and drive you to continuously improve the quality of your campaigns.
Learn more about email marketing tools or get started with Mailchimp or Constant Contact. You can also find out more about our email marketing tool, Autopilot, at autopilot.me
BONUS: Stay up to date on email marketing trends
. Finally, don't underestimate the power of educating yourself on email marketing trends. To keep yourself up-to-date on best practices, subscribe to email marketing thought leader blogs, read industry publications, and attend relevant industry conferences. You'll find that staying informed and up-to-date on email marketing trends can help you develop and execute effective email campaign strategies that produce

instruction: Plan an agenda for the daily standup meetings. Assign a time duration to each topic on the agenda.
output_1:
Daily Standup Meeting Agenda:

1. Check-in (5 minutes): Each team member will provide a brief update on their progress since the last standup.

2. Highlight any blockers (5 minutes): Team members can discuss any impediments or challenges they are facing.

3. Set goals for the day (5 minutes): Team members will set individual goals for the current day and discuss any team goals.

4. Celebrate successes (3 minutes): Team members can celebrate any successes they have achieved since the last standup. 

5. Wrap up (2 minutes): The team leader will review the agenda and provide a summary of the meeting.
output_2: Plan an agenda for the daily standup meetings. Assign a time duration to each topic on the agenda. Decide if you want to start the meeting with a project update or a progress update or any other relevant topic. It is important to stay consistent with the plan so that the team knows what to expect. 2. Engage the Team in the Discussion Engage the team in the discussion. Make sure that someone is taking notes throughout the meeting. Allow room for discussions and feedback from the team. The daily standup process is more productive when all participants are engaged in the process and have a chance to speak up. Keep an open line of communication by encouraging the team to ask questions and seek clarification. 3. Keep it Short Keep the Standup meeting short. It should not take more than 15-20 minutes. The duration should not exceed an hour. Apart from the daily routine, the meeting should be focused and time-efficient. It is important to use the time productively to ensure that nothing is left unattended. This will help in maximizing the team’s potential. 4. Ensure Accountability Ensure accountability and ownership. Assign tasks to each team member and hold them accountable for their progress. Clarify any questions that the team may have regarding the assigned task and ensure follow-up. At the end of the day, each one of us is personally responsible for our actions and the result we produce. Hold the team accountable and help them stay on track. 5. Update the Team with Project Updates Brief the team with the latest progress made on the project. This will keep the team informed, focused, and motivated. Share information regarding any updates, changes, or new strategies. The team will appreciate the transparency, which will encourage them to take ownership and be more accountable for their assigned task. 6. Conclusion In conclusion, daily standup meetings are an effective tool to keep the team aligned, productive, and informed. The key to the success of the daily standup meeting is: Sticking to an agenda, engaging the team in the conversation, keeping it short, ensuring accountability, and staying transparent. By using these tips, you can ensure that your daily standup meetings are productive and meaningful.

instruction:
Answer the following question.

How do you say "good evening" in French.
output_1: Bonsoir.
output_2:
Answer the following question.

How do you say "good evening" in French.

\strong{Correct Answer:} Bon Soir

\strong{Explanation:} "bon" is an informal greeting, while "bonne" is an informal greeting to a woman. "Soir" is the evening time. You would also replace with "bonsoir" (bon+soir) to shorten the greeting.

*For more information, see https://www.duolingo.com/comment/5460355/bon-soir

(In the link, the title of the section on page 62 of the textbook is "Practice - Bonne Soir.", which I assume means Bonne Soir (feminine "soir"?)"?)

2. Answer the following question.

What is the word for "good morning" in French?

\strong{Correct Answer:} Bonjour

\strong{Explanation:} Bonjour is a formal greeting

3. Answer the following question.

In a restaurant, where would you say "Bon appétit!"?

\strong{Correct Answer:} Before you eat, to say that you are going to enjoy your meal

\strong{Explanation:} "Appétit" is a part of the phrase "bien manger" (eat well!) or "s'apprétendre" (to enjoy it)

\strong{Attempt 3}

4. Answer the following question.

Which country(ies) does(do) French have a lot of cognates with?

\strong{Correct Answer:} Spanish (e.g. "parfait" = "perfecto"); Italian (e.g. "gâteau" = "torta")

5. Answer the following question.

Is "Bon appétit!" appropriate for someone you just met or would you say something different?

\strong{Correct Answer:} Depending on the situation, it might be more appropriate to say something different, like "Bon appétit!" in a restaurant or "Bonsoir" if you meet someone in the evening.

6. Answer the following question.

What do you say in French to someone who is sick?

\strong{Correct Answer:} Avez-vous été infecté? (literally, "Have you been infected?")

\strong{Explanation:} It is a common phrase that can be used when you hear someone is sick. This is not a professional medical term, but it is a way to say "are you feeling okay?"

\em{Attempt 4}

7. Answer the following question.

Is "s'il vous plaît" ever used like "excuse moi"?

\strong{Correct Answer:} "Excusez-moi" is a direct translation of "I'm sorry" while s'il vous plaît is a polite way to say Please

\strong{Explanation:} Excuse me is a direct translation of "pardon mes dires". Instead, you would use "S'il vous plaît" ("If you please") to say "Excuse me", and it would be considered polite.

8. Answer the following question.

Is it appropriate to reply "thank you" to someone who says "Bonjour" in French?

\strong{Correct Answer:} Yes, you should usually just say "Merci"

\strong{Explanation:} "Monsieur" is a polite way to say "sir"; in a French restaurant, you should usually address servers and waiters as "Monsieur" or "Madame".

9. Do you say "Bonjour" or "Salut" when you see acquaintances or people you haven't seen in a while?

\strong{Correct Answer:} "Salut" is used when greeting someone as acquaintances or seeing someone you haven't seen in a while

10. Can you explain the difference between the words "merci" and "merci mille fois"?

\strong{Correct Answer:} These are all ways to say thank you in French. "Merci" is the most common and general way to say thank you, while "merci mille fois" literally means "thank you a million times" and it is rare to use it in a professional setting.

11. How can you say "no problem" or "you're welcome" in French?

\strong{Correct Answer:}

instruction: Give a grammar tip on how to end a German verb.
output_1: German verbs are usually ended with "-en" in the infinitive form. For example, "spielen" (to play) or "essen" (to eat).
output_2:
Give a grammar tip on how to end a German verb. 2. What do you call someone who works with cars/as a car mechanic in German? 3. German has different pronouns indicating age and gender. One of them is "du". Can you give another example of a gender neutral pronoun in German? 4. What do you call someone who studies Greek or Latin in German? 5. Is the word "Fahrt" always used in a transport context or do you also say "Fahrwerk" for an engine or "Fahrrad" for a bike? 6. A common question that arises in German is "Was ist das?" or "Was ist los?". German speakers use a diminutive for this question, too, and it's "Was ist das für ein Schnipsel?" Can you explain how to say that in a funny but meaningful way - in German of course? 7. "Es gibt noch nichts." or "Es ist nichts." is common in German. Can you say what their contrasting meaning in German is and give an example? 8. Are there any proverbs or sayings in German that would be interesting or useful in English? Give a few examples! 9. Can you give a few phrases to describe German culture or national characteristics that non-Germans might find interesting or helpful to know? 10. How would an English speaker describe the way German people greet one another? Give an example of a typical greeting and a typical response to that greeting. Thank you! You can also leave a general comment here if you want :)
This lesson took a while to write, but I really enjoyed it and it was well-received by other Language learners when I posted it on Lingotot's website (https://www.lingotot.com/language-resources/german-vocabulary-quiz-adults) I hope it serves you well. Please let me know if you have any questions or comments!
Today we are going to learn about "Wenn" sentences in German. This is basically an extremely important sentence structure in German that we use all the time. But before we delve into it, there are some things you need to know and understand about the language in general: - The verbs in German have three tenses and two voices: the present, the past and the future perfect, and the simple past (indicative tense) and the present continuous (imperative tense). - In German, verbs have many different meanings depending on a few different factors: if the verb is in the middle or end of a sentence, if it is in a positive or negative statement, if it is in a question or an answer, etc. - The verb "Sagen" (= to say/ tell) is an important verb in German, because you can use it to ask many different questions. But a lot of what we ask with "Wenn'...Sagen" is hypothetical, meaning it doesn't have any definite answer because we aren't sure if it's actually going to happen or not. - German has six cases: Nominative (Nominativ), Accusative (Akkusativ), Dativ (Dativ), Genitiv (Genitiv), Vokativ (Vokativ), and Akkusativobjektiv (Akkusativobjektiv). This means that many different variations of a sentence can occur depending on the case and other factors. - German has a lot of exceptions, idioms, and idiomatic ways of saying things that sometimes don't follow typical rules of grammar. This is because they are rooted in German history and tradition, and it's not always possible to create an easy-to-follow and linear way of learning them. With that out of the way, let's delve into "Wenn" sentences! When you see "Wenn" in a sentence in German, what it means is "If" or "When". Here are some examples of "Wenn" sentences in German in various contexts: - "Wenn" man in Deutschland ist, wachsen viele Graswurzeln. If you are in Germany, then you can grow many thistles and other weeds on your lawn. - Wenn du deine Schule besucht hast, dann kannst du mit deinem Klassenzimmer sprechen. If you have been to school, then you can chat with your classmates. - Wenn die Post auf dem Balkon liegt, dann kann dein Brief durch den Sturm gewirbelt werden. If the mailbox is on your balcony, and if it's a windy day, then your letters could be whipped away by

instruction: Come up with healthy and easy dinner ideas for weeknights.
output_1:
1. Veggie stir-fry with brown rice or quinoa
2. Baked salmon with roasted vegetables
3. Noodle-less zucchini lasagna
4. Turkey and black bean tacos
5. Vegetable soup with whole-wheat bread
6. Lentil curry with brown rice
7. Veggie burgers with sweet potato fries
8. Whole-wheat pasta with roasted tomatoes and vegetables
9. Baked chicken thighs with steamed broccoli
10. Grilled vegetable and hummus wrap
output_2:
Come up with healthy and easy dinner ideas for weeknights. The recipe for a healthy diet is to eat a variety of lean foods, whole grains, and lean protein sources.
Dinner is typically the heaviest meal of the day, and it is common sense to choose heartier dinners when compared to lighter snacks or less protein-dense meals.
Starting your meal with a starch helps keep you full longer because the starch is broken down more slowly in your body, and this can help lower your risk of obesity. You have to choose the right kind of starch.
Simple: Complex: Beans and lentils are another type of complex carbs. They are also a great source of protein and fiber.
They contain nutrients like folate, zinc, iron, potassium, and magnesium. These nutrients are essential for optimal brain function and overall health 33.
They are also rich in antioxidants, which can help protect against diseases and reduce inflammation.
Sweet Potatoes: They are also rich in nutrients that benefit the body and mind, including fiber, vitamin C, potassium, and manganese. They are also high in beta-carotene, and their sweet flavor can satisfy your sweet tooth.
Fruits: Some other good examples of fruits that are good sources of complex carbs include apples and pears.
Their nutrient profile is extensive, providing important vitamins like vitamin C, folate, and antioxidants. They also contain fiber, which helps you feel fuller and digest slowly, decreasing the likelihood of overeating.
Whole Grains: These grains have not been separated from their endosperm, bran, and germ. They contain essential nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and fiber. Grains like quinoa, oats, and brown rice are some good examples of whole grains.
Whole grains provide important nutrients that are needed for healthy brain function and cardiovascular health. For example, whole grains are rich in magnesium, which is essential for healthy brain function 34.
Lean Protein Sources Such as chicken, lean beef, turkey, fish, soy products, and nuts. These sources of protein are rich in amino acids that are essential for developing and repairing tissues, and they support proper brain function.
Their high protein content can also keep you feeling full longer.
Eating a variety of foods with different types of nutrients can reduce the risk of heart disease, diabetes, obesity, and other chronic diseases.
Stick to your calorie budget: In order to lose weight, you should try to limit the number of calories you consume. Make sure to track the calories you consume, and the calories you burn.
Aim for at least 160 minutes of exercise every week: exercise doesn’t just help you lose weight, it is also essential for overall health. Exercise helps the body use up stored nutrients like fat cells.
Use smaller plates, bowls, and glasses: Using small dishes can help you eat less. It can also make it easier to stop yourself from overeating.
Eat slowly: chewing slowly helps us enjoy our food better, and it can also help keep us full.
Skip sugary drinks/Soda and opt for water instead: sugar-sweetened drinks give you empty calories and can lead to weight gain.
Start with a starch: Choosing foods that are rich in complex carbs can help keep you feeling full longer and help with weight loss.
Fill half of your plate with veggies: Veggies are packed with fiber and water, and they provide essential vitamins and minerals.
Eat protein with every meal: Proteins are rich in amino acids that can help you feel full and have essential nutrients like zinc and iron.
Include some healthy fats: Healthy fats like those found in nuts, seeds, fatty fish, avocados, and olive oil, are important for maintaining healthy cognitive function and preventing heart disease.
Limit processed foods: processed foods often contain too much sodium, preservatives, additives, and empty calories.
Eat in a calm, relaxed environment: Eating your meals in a relaxed environment can help you taste and enjoy the food you’re eating.
Start with these dinner meal ideas and make your weekn

instruction:
Describe how to prepare the given food in your own words. Note down the ingredients you will need and the steps you will take to prepare them.

Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies
output_1:
Ingredients: 
- 2 ½ cups all-purpose flour
- 1 teaspoon baking soda
- 1 teaspoon salt
- 2 sticks (1 cup) butter, softened
- 1 cup granulated sugar
- 1 cup packed light brown sugar
- 2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract
- 2 large eggs
- 2 cups semisweet chocolate chips

Steps:
1. Preheat oven to 375°F. Line two baking sheets with parchment paper.
2. In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt.
3. In a large bowl, use a hand mixer to cream together the butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar until light and fluffy.
4. Add the vanilla and eggs to the butter mixture and beat until combined.
5. Add the flour mixture to the butter mixture and mix until just combined.
6. Add the chocolate chips and stir until evenly distributed.
7. Using a cookie scoop, scoop the dough onto the prepared baking sheets, about 2 inches apart.
8. Bake for 10-12 minutes until the edges are golden brown.
9. Let cool on the baking sheets for 10 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely. Enjoy!
output_2:
Describe how to prepare the given food in your own words. Note down the ingredients you will need and the steps you will take to prepare them.

Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies Ingredients 1. All purpose flour 2. Baking soda 3. Salt 4. Sugar 5. Butter (Creamed) 6. Chocolate Chips 7. Eggs 

Steps to preparation-

1. Start by preheating the oven at gas mark 5/ 375F

2. Beat together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy.

3. Add a pinch of baking soda and salt.

4. Gradually adds the flour to the mixture and mixes it well.

5. Take your chocolate chip and chopped them into small to size pieces.

6. Add the egg and mix it well.

7. Then lastly add the chocolate chip and mix well till its blend in.

Finally take the mixture into your muffin tray and bake it for about 10-12 minutes

Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies have a nice crispy outer but remain soft in the center like a cake. They are perfect for both home and office snacking.

Cream Cakes Ingredients 1. Flour 2. Sugar 3. Butter (Creamed) 4. Baking powder 5. Milk 6. Eggs 7. Cinnamon Powder 8.

The Steps to preparation-

1. Start by adding butter, sugar and cinnamon powder to a mixing bowl.

2. Then add the baking powder, flour, milk and eggs into the bowl.

3. Mix the ingredients together until well combined.

4. Take a pan, add olive oil to the pan until the oil gets heated.

5. Pour the mixture into the pan and cook the cake until it becomes golden brown.

6. Then take the pan out of the oven and wait for a few minutes before removing the cake.

Cream Cakes are perfect for both home and party snacking. They are rich in taste and are perfect for celebration.

Savory Flatbread Ingrediments 1. All-purpose flour 2. Water 3. Salt 4. Yeast 5. Oil 6. Eggs 7. Tomatoes 8. Bell peppers

Steps to Preparation-

1. Start by dividing the ingredients into three parts.

2. In one part, add flour and salt.

3. In another part, add oil, honey, and yeast.

4. Fold them in the dough until they blend well.

5. Then add in eggs, milk, and vegetables.

6. Cover the bowl and let it rest for an hour.

7. After an hour passes by, preheat the oven to 400-degrees.

8. Meanwhile, make flatbread by adding some oil into a pan.

9. Place the dough onto the pan and cook the flatbread for 4–5 minutes on each side until golden brown.

2. Then in another bowl, add eggs and milk and mix them.

3. Finally, add the flour mixture to the egg mixture and mix the two things together carefully.

4. Then, take a pan or muffin cups and line it with greased liners.

5. Then add batter to the muffin cups and bake for 20-25 minutes.

The chocolate muffins are a perfect breakfast option that goes with a hot cup of coffee or tea.

instruction: Suggest a recipe for a vegan dessert.
output_1:
Vegan Chocolate Fudge Cake
Ingredients: 
- 1 cup all-purpose flour 
- 1/2 cup cocoa powder 
- 1 teaspoon baking powder 
- 1/4 teaspoon salt 
- 1/2 cup vegan butter 
- 1 cup organic sugar 
- 1/2 cup non-dairy milk 
- 1 teaspoon apple cider vinegar 
- 1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 
- 1/2 cup vegan semi-sweet chocolate chips 
- 1/4 cup vegan dark chocolate chips 
Instructions: 
1. Preheat oven to 350°F. Grease and flour a 9-inch cake pan. 
2. In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, and salt. 
3. In a large bowl, beat together the vegan butter and sugar until light and fluffy. 
4. Add the non-dairy milk, apple cider vinegar, and vanilla extract and mix until combined. 
5. Slowly add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix until just combined. 
6. Fold in the vegan chocolate chips. 
7. Pour the batter into the prepared cake pan and spread evenly. 
8. Bake for 25-30 minutes or until a toothpick inserted into the center of the cake comes out clean. 
9. Cool completely before slicing and serving.
output_2: Suggest a recipe for a vegan dessert.

1) (A2) Sudoku puzzle has a common pattern in the upper left corner, the lower left corner and the lower right corner. This pattern tells us that the first unique digit from one of the corners must be either 1 or 2.

2) From the lower left corner, the first unique digits are 4 & 6. We already have a common place value of 1, 2, 3 & 4, so these two must be excluded from the possible values. In Sudoku, values of same integers have to be different from each other.

3) From the remaining three columns, if we assume the first position to be 2, we observe that 8 must be the value of the first position of the fifth column, and 3 must be the value of the first position of the sixth column.

4) If we assume the first position to be 1, we observe that 5 must be the value of the first position of the fifth column, and 6 must be the value of the first position of the sixth column.

5) The value of the first position of the fourth column is 9.

6) The value of the first position of the seventh column is 5.

7) The value of the fourth position of the fifth column is 6.

8) The possible values for all other positions can be derived from the values of the corner positions.

Conclusion: Since we know all of the possible values for all positions, it follows that all of the values for the first three columns are 2, 4 or 5, and all of the values for the sixth and seventh column are 1, 5, and 6. Therefore, this is the solution to the sudoku puzzle:

Think of a motivational quote that you have read in a book. Try to keep it positive and sweet. It reminded me of a quote I had written earlier in my blog. It is a motivational quote that inspired me to do something about my life and to be more productive, creative and self-confidence.
The quote is also for everyone out there who needs a little push to do something positive in their lives. Do not wait another day to pursue your dream, do not wait for better time.
Start now, believe in yourself and take action. Do not worry about the outcomes, just keep focused and work hard for your dreams to come true. Motivate yourself, motivate others who need a little push to excel.
Share your motivational quotations with somebody out there who needs it, don’t let your inspirations go to waste. Let us all continue to be inspired and motivated by others, continue to motivate ourselves and inspire others as well by sharing this inspirational quote with anyone who needs it.

We all have dreams we want to see come true whether it is to change the world, be a great writer, make a positive impact on society, be a better father or mother, etc. Whatever your dreams may be, be sure to believe you can make it. There is no limit to what you can achieve when you have the right mind-set and the strong sense of determination. Remember, you are not alone, do not wait to achieve your dream but start now! Start believing in yourself and motivating yourself.
Be bold, believe in yourself and pursue your dreams with passion. It is difficult to make it sometimes, but keep yourself motivated, keep going and do not give up. Take your time, it is a journey that is worth taking, always keep doing what you do best, and do not let anyone discourage you. After realising the power of her gift, she becomes determined to use her powers to help others, despite her teachers at school attempting to hide her abilities. With the aid of a superbly intelligent friend called Lizzie, Matilda attempts to save her teacher's job, before setting her sights on her parents and her parents' boss.

The story culminates as the parents face their consequences for their actions, and Matilda is saved from their clutches by a group of magical children. Despite the victory, Matilda still faces her own challenges, and learns that despite the power of magic, friendship and determination are what really matter.

I think that this book is well suited for those young readers eager to pick up a book that involves magic, fantasy, friendship, and bravery! CHAPTER 17
An Example of Deductive Argument
The Role of Religion in Public Life
Is it legitimate for a politician to cite religious values when making political decisions and promoting public policies? Or is it improper for a politician to make decisions based on religious values, especially in a diverse society?
This question has divided opinion almost since democracy first developed. On the one hand, supporters of the separation of church and state argue that politicians have a duty to respect the rights of religious minorities and that public officials must be impartial to all religions. On the other hand, advocates of so-called Christian values argue that Christianity forms the bedrock of Western civilization and that politicians must reflect the values of their communities and the majority religion in policy choices. This chapter examines arguments for and against the role of religion in public life, offering a close reading and analysis of key texts by two leading philosophers in the field, William Galston and Mark Lilla.
William Galston and The Role of Religion in Public Life
William Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and frequent contributor to national newspapers, has been a leading proponent of what he calls a "communitarian" approach to church-state issues. Galston defines communitarianism as "the idea that all of us have obligations beyond ourselves toward our family, our friends, our neighbors, our town, our region, our nation, our species, and more." He argues that politicians should be guided by communitarian principles in their decision making, and that religion is a crucial element in building strong communities. "Communitarianism recognizes the need for a shared moral and cultural inheritance," he writes, "and religion is intrinsic to that inheritance." Galston's support for communitarianism comes from his belief in the importance of "social capital"—that is, the collective resources we have as individuals and as communities, including familial, social, and civic bonds—and the value of religion as a source of these resources. Answer: The general formula for $x$ is
$$x={{-b+(-b+2a)}+-2a+b\over a}$$
If $a=0$ then the equation has the form
$$x^2+bx+c=0$$
If $a\ne0$ then the solution is
$$x=\pm{\sqrt b\over 2a}+{\sqrt b\over 2a}\coth\left({1\over 2a}\right)$$
Using $b=-6,c=24$ and $a=1$, we have
$$x=1-{\coth(1)\over 2}+{1\over 2}\pm{1\over 2} {\coth\left({1\over 2}\right)\over \sqrt 6}
-{1\over 2}{\cosh \left({1\over 2}\right)\over \sqrt 6} \quad$$
and hence
$$\min x=-{\coth(1)\over 2}\pm 1/2,$$
and
$$\max x=1/2 - {\coth (1)\over 2} \approx 1.045$$

Answer: Note that $x$ can be written as $$x = \frac{\sqrt {-6 + 4(-2 + (-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(4-3)))))-4))))}{2} + \frac{\sqrt {(-6 + 4(2-(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(4-3)))))-4))))}}{2}\coth (\frac {1}{2}) - 1$$

Let $a = \sqrt {-6 + 4(2-(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(4-3)))))-4))))}$ and $b = \sqrt {(-6 + 4(2-(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(-6 + 2(4-3)))))-4)))))}$ then we can write $$x = 4 - 3\coth(\frac{1}{2}) = 4 - 3\tanh(\frac{1}{2}) = 4(1 - \tanh(\frac{1}{2}))$$ and finally, we can write $$\min_x x = 4 - \tanh(\frac{1}{2}) < 4 - 0.945 < 4 - 0.226 = 1.857 > \min_x x$$

instruction:
Prove the given statement using your information.

"If x is a positive integer or a solution to x+3>4, then x>0 and x>12."
output_1: Since x is a positive integer, it follows that x>0. Additionally, since x+3>4, then x>1. These two conditions together imply that x>12. Therefore, the statement is true.
output_2:

"If x is a positive integer or a solution to x+3>4, then x>0 and x>12."

Comment: @A.P I have already proved that

Comment: What do you mean by “using your information”? What information have you already given?  If you want us to help you, you need to  be more explicit about your intent, and provide more specific information.

Answer: From the given statement we can deduce that:

$x$ is a positive integer or it is a solution to the equation $x+3>4$.

If $x$ is a positive integer, then it belongs to the set $\{(x, x+3,x+4) : x \geq 0 \}$ and thus it satisfies the two conditions $x>0$ and $x > 12$.

Suppose that $x$ is a solution to the equation $x+3 > 4$. Then, there must exists an integer $y$ such that $x + y = 4$. Because, $x+3 > x+y=4$  and hence $y$ is a solution to the equation $x+y = 4$ and thus must be an integer. However, $y$ can also be any positive integer as well. Hence the statement "x is a positive integer or a solution to the equation $x + 3 > 4$" implies $x > 0$ and $x > 12$.

Thus, we can conclude that the given statement holds true for positive integers $x$ which are either solutions to the equation $x + 3 > 4$ or belong to the set $\{(x, x+3,x+4) : x \geq 0 \}$.

instruction:
Based on the facts that have been provided, prove the following statement.

Statement: "For every integer k, k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0"
Fact: The square of any real number is non-negative.
output_1:
Proof:
Let k be an integer. Since the square of any real number is non-negative, k^2 ≥ 0. Therefore,

k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0

Let k = 0. Then,

0 + 0 + 1 ≥ 0

which is true.

Now let k be an integer such that k ≠ 0. Then,

k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0

This is true because the sum of the non-negative number k^2 and the non-negative number 2k is always non-negative.

Therefore, for every integer k, k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0.
output_2:
Based on the facts that have been provided, prove the following statement.

Statement: "For every integer k, k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0"
Fact: The square of any real number is non-negative.
Conclusion (Inductive Reasoning): For all integers k, k² + 2k + 1 ≥ 0.

Therefore: "Prove that 0² + 0 + 1 ≥ 0."

Inductive Reasoning is a form of logical deduction. In this example, the two statements being proven are the positive square of all integers and the sum of all integers being non-negative. The induction step is given in the conclusion, which states "Prove that 0² + 0 + 1 ≥ 0." This is the step that proves that the induction conclusion is true. As a result, it is valid and consistent. Inductive reasoning leads to the general conclusion.

The key to effective induction reasoning is firstly to state the problem and list all the relevant facts or information that you know. Next, you can establish a relationship between those known facts and the conclusion. Finally, you can extend the relationship to demonstrate the truth of the general conclusion. In this example, given the information the square of any real number is non-negative. and the following fact, for all integers k, k² + 2k + 1 ≥ 0, the conclusion is proven that 0² + 0 + 1 ≥ 0.

Reasoning by cases

Reasoning by cases is a form of inductive reasoning that consists of three steps:

1. Identify the cases: The problem's variables are named and stated.
2. Induce the general conclusion: From the cases, general conclusions are drawn.
3. Check the general conclusion: The conclusion is checked for errors using its hypotheses.

The key to reasoning by cases is to identify the cases that will hold true within the context, the generalization, or the situation. In this example, we have to identify the cases. The cases are the integers k from 1 to infinity such that:

for all integers k, k² + 2k + 1 ≥ 0.

So, it is necessary to identify the cases from the given information. Next, we have to draw general conclusions from those cases. In this example, the general conclusion is as follows:

0² + 0 + 1 ≥ 0.

Finally, we have to check the general conclusion using its hypotheses. In this example, the cases are the integers from 1 to infinity. Therefore, the hypothesis is that k² + 2k + 1 ≥ 0 for all integers k from 1 to infinity. So, the proof can begin by stating those hypotheses, and then the induction can be attempted.

The argument is valid even though it has not been proven true for all k. But it can be used for any positive integer that is not zero, thereby covering a wide range of possible real numbers.

The following is an example of Reasoning by Cases, and it demonstrates how a simple inductive argument can be expressed more formally.

Premise: 0² = 0

Evidence: 0² = positive since 0² is real number 0 = 0 positive

Conclusion: For all positive numbers a, 

a² = a

Reasoning by cases:

Identify the cases:

1. Positive a

Conclusion: A generalization of the evidence from the case 1:

For any positive number a:

a² = a
2. Negative a

Conclusion: A generalization of the evidence from the case 2:

For any negative number a:

a² = -a

Checking the general conclusion:

Using the hypothesis that 0² = 0, the concluding statements for any positive and non-zero a can be checked:

0² = 0

1. a² = a

2. -a² = -a

3. a² = a

4. -a² = -a

All four statements are consistent, and so the conclusion is sound

This demonstrates that reasoning by cases is a powerful method to create an argument, especially for more complex problems where complex data analysis might not be feasible. Once the cases are identified, it becomes easy to arrive at the desired conclusion. Moreover, the reasoning is both sound and deductive in nature, which means that it can be used as a valid inference.

Induction is based on inductive reasoning

"For all integers j and k, if j and k are odd, then jk is odd."

(A) True
(B) False
(C) Cannot determine without additional information
(D) Depends on the value of j and k
(E) Depends on whether j and k are positive or negative integers.

Let j be an odd integer.

Then, j is positive

Let k be an odd integer.

Then, k is positive

Since the product of two positive integers is positive, the product of j and k is positive.

Therefore (D) cannot be true in general.

Since jk is the product of two positive integers, we know that jk is positive unless (c) holds.

(A)	TRUE: The conclusion of the premise of this statement is correct, so the statement is true.

(B)	FALSE: This statement is not true in general. Even if j and k are odd integers, the product of j and k may still be even. For example, the integers 3 and 4, whose product is 12, are both odd, but the product 12 is even.

(C)	CANNOT DETERMINE WITHOUT ADDITIONAL INFORMATION: The statement does not provide additional information about j and k.

(D)	DEPENDS ON THE VALUES OF J AND K: The product of two odd integers is always odd unless both values of j and k are even. Hence, statement (D) cannot be correct in general.

(E)	DEPENDS ON WHETHER J AND K ARE POSITIVE OR NEGATIVE INTEGERS: The statement assumes that j and k are positive integers. However, this is not true in general. In some cases, j and k may be negative integers, in which case the statement is not true.

&=5+n(n-1)(n-2)\left(\frac{2(n-1)}{(n-1)^2}\right)\\
&=5+n(n-1)(n-2)\left((\frac 23)^n-(\frac 23)^{n-1}\right)\\
&=5+n(n-1)(n-2)+(2n-1)(2)\left((\frac 23)^n-(\frac 23)^{n-1}\right)\\

Thus the formula for the nth term is

$$x=5+(n-1)(n-2)+(2n-1)(2)\left((\frac 23)^n-(\frac 23)^{n-1}\right)$$

Important points that you must consider:

\begin{itemize}
\item You should allow for both real and fictional users, and therefore both users may be humans or bots.
\item You should not rely on API integrations, as participants of a conversation may not be willing to expose the data of the messages outside of the conversation.
\item The challenge is to be able to handle any messaging app or messaging platform, as long as it can store the messages, so it may be an online messaging or offline messaging app, depending on the chosen platform.
\item Remember that you need to follow the guidelines of the chosen platform, therefore if the guidelines require you to have permission to access the app data, you need to have the permission.
\end{itemize}

Note: The challenge may be modified to include a scoring system, where additional points are awarded for meeting the goal within a set amount of time.

A simple summarize AI is an NLU model combined with a sentiment analysis model that gives a numerical score for the confidence of the language used by customer.

### Knowledge-based NLP

These tools are known as knowledge-based NLP tools and are based on a model that analyzes a corpus of text that has been labeled with categories that denote the concepts and entities that the system encounters.

Knowledge-based NLP uses rules to handle natural language. It is based on a set of rules that the system uses to build semantic representations from raw text to extract meaning and identify concepts.

The rules are programmed with a pre-defined terminology and syntax to be able to analyze and extract elements from a piece of text. It can also use statistical patterns to analyze text and categorize it.

For example, a knowledge-based NLP tool would be able to extract a sentence from a document consisting of nouns, verbs, and adjectives; this knowledge-based model can assign certain semantic meaning to those nouns, verbs, and adjectives, to form complete sentences.

Knowledge-based NLP tools have the advantage of being easy to implement and have low maintenance. Its downfall is that it is a relatively static process as rules and patterns are fixed and often require reprogramming when new concepts or terminologies arise.

A knowledge-based NLP tool used in a chatbot may be asked to interpret text to classify the customer's problem, suggest solutions or recommend relevant content based on category names, phrases, or patterns.

### Language models

Language models have a long history in natural language processing. The first formal theory of language models was proposed by Stephen Thurston in his 1996 paper, "The Role of Language Models in Recognizing Unfamiliar Words".

The objective of language models is to characterize the statistical properties of a corpus of text, with the goal of being able to predict the most likely next word given the current word or words in a sequence. Language models are also used for text analysis; the model is fed a set of text, and based on the pattern it discovers from the text, it calculates the probable output based on statistical probability. These models are widely used in various Natural Language Processing (NLP) applications, such as, language translation, speech recognition, and information retrieval.

Language models are used in the chatbot process, to understand the language conversation and suggest context-appropriate responses. Language models are also used in automatic speech recognition applications, which involves transcribing human speech into machine-readable text, or understanding a single word.

### Neural Networks

Neural Networks have been used extensively in the field of natural language processing due to their ability to learn from complex data, and extract non-linear features from text. 

These networks can learn to map complex sequences of characters to a series of discrete outputs, which is based on statistical behavior or patterns that are detected within the data. This means that the neural network can learn to associate a unique pattern with a particular semantic meaning, allowing the system to process language without having to be explicitly programmed with rules and heuristics.

The network is trained using the labeled data. This labeled data is made of sentences (or sentences fragments) that are paired with semantic labels (i.e., the class to which the sentence belongs, like weather, recipe, etc.). During the training phase, the neural network attempts to map each input to the most likely output given a set of constraints such as the maximum number of steps that can be taken to the output, the number of inputs it can handle, etc.

Much like other NLP technologies, neural networks are used in chatbots, for language translation from one language to another, and in automatic speech recognition applications.

For example, a chatbot can use neural networks to understand the customer's intent from their text conversation and provide context-appropriate responses. 

## See also

* Natural language generation
* Natural language processing
* NLP for business

instruction:
Describe the content of the article in a brief manner.

A study published earlier this year by Zee and her team examined the role of light in sleep for healthy adults in their 20s. Sleeping for only one night with a dim light, such as a TV set with the sound off, raised the blood sugar and heart rate of the young people during the sleep lab experiment. An elevated heart rate at night has been shown in prior studies to be a risk factor for future heart disease and early death, while higher blood sugar levels are a sign of insulin resistance, which can ultimately lead to type 2 diabetes.
output_1: This article discusses a study that found that sleeping with a dim light, such as a TV set with the sound off, can raise blood sugar and heart rate in healthy adults in their 20s. Elevated heart rate at night has been linked to future heart disease and early death, while higher blood sugar levels are a sign of insulin resistance and can lead to type 2 diabetes.
output_2:
Describe the content of the article in a brief manner.

A study published earlier this year by Zee and her team examined the role of light in sleep for healthy adults in their 20s. Sleeping for only one night with a dim light, such as a TV set with the sound off, raised the blood sugar and heart rate of the young people during the sleep lab experiment. An elevated heart rate at night has been shown in prior studies to be a risk factor for future heart disease and early death, while higher blood sugar levels are a sign of insulin resistance, which can ultimately lead to type 2 diabetes.

Explain how the article contributes to the field of health and medicine.

The study shows how light at nighttime can have a negative effect on metabolism and heart rate, and may lead to health problems like type 2 diabetes and obesity. While prior studies have suggested that light can impact circadian rhythms, this is the first to examine the specific effects of light on heart rhythms, as well as on blood sugar. Researchers have also shown in prior studies that light exposure can affect melatonin production, which is an important hormone for regulating sleep-wake cycles, as well as other processes inside the body.

Explain the purpose of the article and how the author(s) meet(s) that purpose.

The purpose of this article was to examine the effect of dim light on resting heart rate and blood sugar levels in healthy adults. The authors of the study, led by Zee, recruited young adults and split them into two groups: Those who slept in total darkness, and those who slept with a dim light in the room. The researchers measured participants' heart rate and blood sugar levels before and after sleeping, and compared the results between the two groups. Overall, participants who slept in total darkness showed significantly lower heart rates and lower blood sugar levels compared to those who slept with a dim light in the room.

Explain the audience for whom the article was written and their level of knowledge regarding the article’s topic.

This article was written for health professionals and those interested in cardiovascular endocrinology, as well as the general public. It’s written at a level that’s accessible to someone who hasn’t necessarily studied or worked in the field of medicine, but it is still informative enough for someone with an academic background to benefit from it too.

 Explain how the article was organized and if it follows a specific format.

The article is organized in a well-structured format. The first section establishes the background, giving readers an idea of what the study was about, who it was conducted on, the purpose, and the results. The second section examines the findings, discussing the effect of light on metabolism. The last section is a summary of the main points of the article and its implications for future research.

Explain the tone, language use, and any stylistic devices used by the author(s).

The language of the article is clear and concise, with no unusual, flowery or academic language used. The tone is neutral and provides key pieces of information to the readers. The article is written in a logical manner, with sections clearly defined and easy to follow.

Explain any limitations of the article or other sources used. Were there any biases or gaps in the sources?

The main limitation of the article is that the research only involved young, healthy adults in their early 20s, and the study’s findings may not necessarily apply to the wider population.

It won't reverse my interest charge as the charge has already taken place. Comment: I am surprised that the bank actually processed the interest charge without notice that it was being billed, if it was a mistake. Banks typically inform customers when a late payment charges are posted to their account. Perhaps it would be worth reaching out to the account manager directly and discussing the matter with them, or escalating to someone higher up if that does not resolve the issue.

Answer: You can reverse the interest charge before the 60 day period by having direct contact with the issuer of the credit card. In your case, that might require further discussion with the lender's customer service department or a manager dealing with this matter. You could explain the misunderstanding and provide documentary proof of your position, such as a canceled check for your payment, or your bank statement showing the payment received before the due date. This is especially true of credit card lenders, since they can charge exorbitant interest rates and also be sued for bad faith or for violations of laws or policies.

As of October, 2021, 40-43 days after the statement date is the absolute last day your credit card lender can waive the late fee and charge interest to your account if you're late on a minimum payment. A missed minimum payment can still result in a penalty rate that's around 29% (variable rates), and you're required to continue making that payment for three more billing cycles. After that period, the lender is required by law to assess your account for any past due balance or default. If you contact the lender during that time, you may find that they are willing to work things out on a case-by-case basis.

Note: There is generally no obligation on a credit card lender to waive interest charges or other
